reasoning: The critique targets a real load-bearing piece of one strand of the essay: the claim that (on linear-in-resources views) achieving a mostly-great future requires capturing essentially all accessible cosmic resources, motivating “scale-based” fussiness. However, the essay’s overall “no easy eutopia” conclusion is also supported by several largely independent arguments (fragility/multiplicative factors; moral-catastrophe-by-default considerations; and bounded-view fussiness via sensitivity to bads and aggregation), so even a strong hit to the scale/cosmic-expansion premise would only partially weaken the position (moderate centrality). The argument’s refutation force is limited: even if competition or strategic choice reduces what’s practically reachable, the essay’s notion of ‘best feasible future’ is percentile-based relative to a feasibility/likelihood distribution, so the target can shrink with the resource set rather than making fussiness “moot.” Also, ‘linear views become similar to bounded views in practice’ is not generally true: linear vs bounded is primarily about how value scales, not the absolute size of the resource endowment. Still, the point that the paper treats ‘affectable universe’ as exogenous and single-agent, and that multi-agent equilibrium/competition could change the relevant feasible scale, is plausible and relevant (decent correctness). The critique is clear, focused, and contains little fluff.
title: Competitive dynamics between civilizations may drastically shrink accessible resources
